content: The "Charitable Pension Flexibility Act of 2013" allows eligible charity plans to elect to cease being treated as such. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 is amended to allow plan sponsors to elect for a plan to no longer be treated as an eligible charity plan starting from 2014. The election must be made as prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury and can only be revoked with their consent. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect for a plan to apply certain rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. The election must be made as prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury and can only be revoked with their consent. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect for a plan to apply certain rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. The plan has 11-year, 12-year, and 7-year shortfall amortization bases. The determination of installments is based on specific rules under the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect for a plan to apply certain rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. The rules involve adjusting the shortfall amortization base period from 7 years to 12 years. Specific provisions under the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act apply to plans with this election, with the first plan year after December 31, 2013, considered as the election year. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect for a plan to apply certain rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. References to specific dates in the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act are adjusted to February 28, 2013, and March 1, 2013. The 11-year shortfall amortization base is determined for the first plan year beginning after December 31, 2013. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect certain rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013. This includes provisions from the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The plan's shortfall amortization base is determined for the first plan year beginning after December 31, 2013. The Pension Protection Act of 2006 allows plan sponsors to elect rules for plan years starting after December 31, 2013, including provisions from the Internal Revenue Code and the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. The 12-year shortfall amortization base is determined for the first plan year beginning after December 31, 2009, with specific conditions outlined. The 12-year shortfall amortization base is an amount determined for the first plan year beginning after December 31, 2013, equal to the unamortized principal amount of the shortfall amortization base that would have applied to the plan for the first plan year beginning after December 31, 2010, under certain conditions. The text discusses the application of section 430(c)(2)(D)(iii) of the Internal Revenue Code and section 303(c)(2)(D)(iii) of the Employee Retirement Income Security Act to the shortfall amortization base for the first plan year starting after December 31, 2010. It also mentions that no events occurred that would have modified the shortfall as of the first day of the first plan year after December 31, 2013. The text discusses the 7-year shortfall amortization base for the first plan year starting after December 31, 2013, which is calculated by subtracting the sum of the 11-year and 12-year shortfall amortization bases from the base without regard to this paragraph. The amendments made by this section regarding the 7-year shortfall amortization base will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
